translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The third section
The discussion of knowledge in accordance with deeds

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: Is knowledge in accordance with deeds the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: Yathākammūpagatañca manasi karoti, dibbena cakkhunā rūpaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: yathākammūpagatam ca manasi karoti dibbena cakkhunā rūpam passati iti
translated: And does one pay attention to in accordance with deeds and see a visible form with the divine eye?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Yathākammūpagatañca manasi karoti, dibbena cakkhunā rūpaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: yathākammūpagatam ca manasi karoti dibbena cakkhunā rūpam passati iti
translated: And does one pay attention to in accordance with deeds and see a visible form with the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: Dvinnaṁ phassānaṁ dvinnaṁ cittānaṁ samodhānaṁ hotīti?
analyzed: dvinnam phassānam dvinnam cittānam samodhānam hoti iti
translated: Is there a coming together of two contacts and two consciousnesses?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: Is knowledge in accordance with deeds the divine eye?
“Yes.”

original: “Ime vata bhonto sattā”ti ca manasi karoti, “kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā”ti ca manasi🔽karoti, “vacīduccaritena samannāgatā”ti ca manasi karoti, “manoduccaritena samannāgatā”ti
analyzed: ime vata bhonto sattā ati ca manasi karoti kāya duccaritena samannāgatā ati ca manasi  karoti vacīduccaritena samannāgatā ati ca manasi karoti manoduccaritena samannāgatā ati
translated: One pays attention to “These beings” and pays attention to “are endowed with bodily good conduct,”🔽pays attention to “are endowed with verbal good conduct,”🔽pays attention to “are endowed with mental good conduct,”

original: ca manasi karoti, “ariyānaṁ upavādakā”ti ca manasi karoti, “micchādiṭṭhikā”ti ca
analyzed: ca manasi karoti ariyānam upavādakā ati ca manasi karoti micchādiṭṭhikā ati ca
translated: pays attention to “are reproachable,” pays attention to “have wrong view,”

original: manasi karoti, “micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā”ti ca manasi karoti, “te kāyassa bhedā🔽paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā”ti ca manasi karoti, “ime
analyzed: manasi karoti micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā ati ca manasi karoti te kāyassa bhedā  param maraṇāḥ apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannā ati ca manasi karoti ime
translated: he brings to mind, ‘They have undertaken wrong view,’ and he brings to mind, ‘With the breakup of the body, after death, they are reborn in a lower realm,

original: vā pana bhonto sattā”ti ca manasi karoti, “kāyasucaritena samannāgatā”ti ca manasi
analyzed: vā pana bhonto sattā ati ca manasi karoti kāya su caritena samannāgatā ati ca manasi
translated: a bad destination, a state of misery, a world of suffering, hell,’ and he brings to mind, ‘These beings,’ and he brings to mind, ‘Endowed with bodily good conduct …’🔽and he brings to mind, ‘Endowed with verbal good conduct …’

original: karoti, “vacīsucaritena samannāgatā”ti ca manasi karoti, “manosucaritena samannāgatā”ti🔽ca manasi karoti, “ariyānaṁ anupavādakā”ti ca manasi karoti, “sammādiṭṭhikā”ti ca🔽manasi karoti, “sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā”ti ca manasi karoti, “te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ
analyzed: karoti vacī su caritena samannāgatā ati ca manasi karoti manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā ati  ca manasi karoti ariyānam an upavādakā ati ca manasi karoti sammādiṭṭhikā ati ca  manasi karoti sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā ati ca manasi karoti te kāyassa bhedā
translated: and he brings to mind, ‘Endowed with mental good conduct …’🔽and he brings to mind, ‘Blameless regarding the noble ones …’

original: maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā”ti ca manasi karoti, dibbena cakkhunā rūpaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati ca manasi karoti dibbena cakkhunā rūpam passati iti
translated: and he brings to mind, ‘Right view,’ and he brings to mind, ‘They have undertaken right view,’ and he brings to mind, ‘With the breakup of the body, after death, they are reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world,’ and he sees a form with the divine eye: does he see it as it actually is or not?”
“You shouldn’t say that …

original: “Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā”ti ca manasi karoti, dibbena cakkhunā rūpaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati ca manasi karoti dibbena cakkhunā rūpam passati iti
translated: “He pays attention to the fact that, with the breakup of the body, after death, they have reappeared in a good destination, in a heavenly world. He sees with the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human, beings passing away and arising: inferior and superior, fair and ugly, in a good destination or a bad destination. He understands how beings pass on according to their actions.”
“Yes.”

original: Dvinnaṁ phassānaṁ dvinnaṁ cittānaṁ samodhānaṁ hotīti?
analyzed: dvinnam phassānam dvinnam cittānam samodhānam hoti iti
translated: “Are there two kinds of contact and two kinds of consciousness?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: “Is knowledge of passing away and re-appearance the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi koci adibbacakkhuko dibbacakkhuṁ appaṭiladdho anadhigato asacchikato yathākammūpagataṁ jānātīti?
analyzed: atthi koci a dibba cakkhukaḥ dibba cakkhum a paṭiladdhaḥ an adhigataḥ a sacchikataḥ yathākammūpagatam jānāti iti
translated: “Is there anyone who, without divine eye, without having attained to the divine eye, knows of passing away and re-appearance?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci atthi koci adibbacakkhuko dibbacakkhuṁ appaṭiladdho anadhigato asacchikato yathākammūpagataṁ jānāti, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci atthi koci adibba cakkhukaḥ dibba cakkhum appaṭiladdhaḥ anadhigataḥ asacchikataḥ yathākammūpagatam jānāti no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: “Then it is not true that knowledge of passing away and re-appearance is the divine eye.”

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: “Is knowledge of passing away and re-appearance the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: āyasmā sāriputtaḥ yathā kammu upagatam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “Does the Venerable Sariputta know of passing away and re-appearance?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci āyasmā sāriputto yathākammūpagataṁ ñāṇaṁ jānāti, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci āyasmā sāriputtaḥ yathā kammu upagatam ñāṇam jānāti no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Does Venerable Sāriputta know with knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions that the knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions is the divine eye?”

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: “No, it’s not appropriate to say that.”

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: “Is the knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions the divine eye?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: āyasmā sāriputtaḥ yathā kammu upagatam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “Does Venerable Sāriputta know with knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions that the knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions is the divine eye?”
“Yes.”
“Does Venerable Sāriputta have the divine eye?”
“You shouldn’t say that.”
“Does Venerable Sāriputta have the divine eye?”
“Yes.”
“Didn’t Venerable Sāriputta say this:
‘I have no desire for recollecting my past lives,

analyzed: na pi dibbassa cakkhuno  id dhiyā  sota dhātu visuddhiyā
translated: Or for the divine eye,🔽Or for reading the minds of others,🔽Or for the divine ear,
Or for knowing the passing away and rebirth of beings.
I have no such desire.’
“Is there such a discourse?”
“Yes.”
“Well then, you shouldn’t say that

analyzed: yathā kammūpagatam ñāṇam dibba cakkhun ti
translated: the knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions is the divine eye.”
The discussion of the knowledge of how beings are affected by their actions is finished.
